newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX oil complex suffers 'technical meltdown'.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX oil complex suffers 'technical meltdown'.

text.p: The NYMEX oil complex suffered a "technical meltdown" in the final hour of trade Wednesday afternoon after a day that saw crude hold support then test resistance in the earlier going, traders.
Whether crude or gasoline led the breakdown remained a subject of disagreement, but with a lack of substantial news in the market, no one denied the fall was technical in nature.

"It was basically a technical meltdown," said one floor trader who linked the move to May crude, which turned its back on bullish inventory data and ended up shedding 35 cents and settling a $20.64 a barrel.

May crude plunged through a congested area of support between $20.80 and $20.90 a barrel in the final half hour of trade, with support now seen at levels including $20.15, $20 and $19.78, traders said.

"Everything technical I had got blown away. We're back to square one," said another trader, who watched what he had identified as a reverse head and shoulders formation on May gasoline melt down in the final turbulent half hour.
April gasoline lost 1.70 cents and settled at 64.82 cents a gallon, while April heating oil, going along for the ride, lost 1.40 cents ending at 55.43 cents a gallon.
"Which one decided to head down? I'm going to say it was gasoline. But it's hard to say," said Tom Bentz, analyst at ING Derivatives Clearing in New York.
"A lot of the length that was in the market bailed out when it went below 66.00 cents," Bentz said. Other sources see the next support at 64.40.

Some sources said there were clear fundamental factors that justified the drop, including a still-sloppy North Sea crude market, as well as voluminous blendstock imports hiding deep in the American Petroleum Institute's (API) weekly data.
"I'm not surprised," said Jim Ritterbusch, a trader with Sweeney Oil in Chicago who also viewed gasoline as the main influence in the selloff.
He said that while higher refinery runs may bring relief to a well-supplied crude market, it will also bring extra gasoline supplies onto the market.
Others said refiner crack spread selling on gasoline finally caught the attention of locals who were caught long as the market moved through its support levels Wednesday.
The May gasoline-to-crude crack spread lost 40 cents Wednesday, settling at $6.37 a barrel.
Still, some traders said the sharp selloff, while rather precipitous, did not violate the three-week uptrend seen in NYMEX markets.
"It is in danger of breaking its three-week uptrend, but I am not ready at this point to throw in the bullish towel," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil.
-- Oliver Ludwig, New York Energy Desk, 1 212 859 1633
